We practice earthquake drills 2x a year, but when people don’t know because they have never experienced an earthquake, it’s hard to really understand what an earthquake feels like and what the procedure means. I, personally, have never experienced an earthquake so I would only be able to tell what I’ve heard the experience is like.

Teacher Judy said it best to talk with your child in a matter of fact voice about what they experienced today and what they should do an earthquake. We will do our best to reinforce procedure throughout the year and in our drills.

Take care and we will see everybody Monday.

Ms. Nieraeth

Parents....Just a thought...

In school we practice earthquake drills but it is hard to drill something children have never experienced. If your child felt the earthquake, you might want to simply say "That was an earthquake. When the ground shakes like that, things could fall off the walls. This is why teachers at school might call out DUCK AND COVER! Get under a table or stand in a doorway to help protect yourself."

It can be said in a simple matter of fact way not to frighten your child but to help them begin to understand what earthquake means.

Keep safe and love to you all,
Teacher Judy Miles

Due to National Weather Service's freeze warning for tomorrow morning, 2CJ will be on their Late Start Schedule for Thursday, January 5. Buses will run their routes 2 hours later in the morning and school will start at 10am. If your student is a walker or you drop them off, please do not have them to school before 9:35am to give our staff plenty of time to safely get to work.

Release time in the afternoon will be normal. After school activities will go on as usual.

If you have not already, please sign up for our Flash Alert at http://www.2cj.com to keep up to date on school closures and delays. As always, check our Facebook pages for the most updated information.
